title: China Eximbank provides buyer’s credit loan for Tehran Metro Line 4 Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#41122 and ID#41123)
description: Preliminary agreements on the construction of Tehran Metro Line 4 began during Iranian President Mohammad Khatami's state visit to China on June 23, 2000. Then, on June 15, 2004, China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO) — a Chinese state owned enterprise (SOE) — signed a $836,000,000 engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract with Tehran Urban and Suburban Railway Company (TUSRC) for the Tehran Metro Line 4 Construction Project. China Eximbank reportedly issued a buyer’s credit loan to support the financing of the EPC contract. This loan was also reportedly insured by China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure).   The purpose of the project was to construct a 22 km metro line (‘Line 4’) — running from east to west in the city of Tehran — that links 19 metro stations. Line 4 was constructed in four sections (phases). Section 1 runs from Ferdowsi Square to Darvazeh Shemiran. Section 2 runs from Darvazeh Shemiran to Shohada Square. Section 3 runs from Ferdowsi Square to Engelab Square. Section 4 runs from Meydan-e Azadi to Ekbatan. NORINCO entrusted the project's implementation and financing to NORINCO International Cooperation LTD., its wholly owned subsidiary.   Construction on Section 1 began in June 2007 and it opened on April 19, 2008. Section 2 opened on March 16, 2009. Section 3 opened on May 31, 2009. Section 4 opened on July 23, 2012.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 德黑兰地铁4号线项目 or 北方工业公司承包德黑兰地铁项目 or 德黑兰地铁4号线 or 德黑兰地铁4号线项目. . 2. The face value of the buyer’s credit loan from China Eximbank is unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes that the face value of the loan is equivalent to 85% of the value of the $836 million commercial (EPC) contract between TUSRC and NORINCO ($710.6 million).
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides buyer’s credit loan for Tehran Metro Line 4 Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#41122 and ID#41123)

# Description
Preliminary agreements on the construction of Tehran Metro Line 4 began during Iranian President Mohammad Khatami's state visit to China on June 23, 2000. Then, on June 15, 2004, China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO) — a Chinese state owned enterprise (SOE) — signed a $836,000,000 engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract with Tehran Urban and Suburban Railway Company (TUSRC) for the Tehran Metro Line 4 Construction Project. China Eximbank reportedly issued a buyer’s credit loan to support the financing of the EPC contract. This loan was also reportedly insured by China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure).   The purpose of the project was to construct a 22 km metro line (‘Line 4’) — running from east to west in the city of Tehran — that links 19 metro stations. Line 4 was constructed in four sections (phases). Section 1 runs from Ferdowsi Square to Darvazeh Shemiran. Section 2 runs from Darvazeh Shemiran to Shohada Square. Section 3 runs from Ferdowsi Square to Engelab Square. Section 4 runs from Meydan-e Azadi to Ekbatan. NORINCO entrusted the project's implementation and financing to NORINCO International Cooperation LTD., its wholly owned subsidiary.   Construction on Section 1 began in June 2007 and it opened on April 19, 2008. Section 2 opened on March 16, 2009. Section 3 opened on May 31, 2009. Section 4 opened on July 23, 2012.
justification: Project is focused on urban transportation infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of 22 km metro line with 19 stations, general urban transportation infrastructure

title: Chinese Embassy Donates 1,000 copies of 'Tongjian' to Hebrew University of Jerusalem
description: On July 8, 2004, Chinese ambassador to Israel Chen Yonglong donated 1,000 copies of the Chinese book "Tongjian" to the Hebrew University of Jerusalem's  school on Chinese culture and archaeology.

title: China donates toys and writing materials to children in Jamaica
description: On November 24, 2004, the Chinese ambassador met with Governor-General of Jamaica and the First Lady at the King's House and provided the First Lady children's toys and writing materials worth US$500. The toys will be sent to children in need living around Montego Bay for Christmas.
combined_text:

OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

justification: Project involves donation of toys and writing materials to children, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of toys and writing materials, focus on social welfare and children's needs

title: Chinese Government provides $1.2 million grant for provision of school equipment
description: On October 14, 2004, during King Abdullah's visit to China, the acting Jordanian Planning and International Cooperation Minister Hazem Al Nasser and Chinese deputy commerce minister Liao Xiaoqi signed a $1.2 million grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to equip 21 schools and support an information center within the Prime Minister's Office. This agreement represented the fulfillment of pledges that were made during the visit of King Abdullah II to China in July 2004.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides $1.2 million grant for provision of school equipment

# Description
On October 14, 2004, during King Abdullah's visit to China, the acting Jordanian Planning and International Cooperation Minister Hazem Al Nasser and Chinese deputy commerce minister Liao Xiaoqi signed a $1.2 million grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to equip 21 schools and support an information center within the Prime Minister's Office. This agreement represented the fulfillment of pledges that were made during the visit of King Abdullah II to China in July 2004.
justification: Project focuses on education and school equipment without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of school equipment, support for information center, education sector focus

title: Chinese Embassy grants 5,000 garments to the JNRCS in 2004
description: On August 12, 2004, Mohammed Hadid, the President of the Jordan National Red Crescent Society (JNRCS), received a donation of 5,000 pieces of garments from the Chinese Charge d’affaires ad interim, Mr. Li Chen. According to an article by the Chinese Embassy in Jordan, Chinese enterprises manufactured the garments, yet the specific firms are unknown.

title: China National Petroleum Corporation provides $1.35 million USD to set up a scholarship for Kazakhstani students to study in China
description: On September 27, 2004, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) signed an agreement with the Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan in which CNPC agreed to provide $1.35 million USD to the ministry for the creation of the "Presidential Scholarship." The scholarship was to finance higher level education in China for excellent Kazakhstani students. The scholarship fund was active as of September 2011.
staff_comments: 1. 'Project status' was coded as 'Completion' because CNPC stated in 2008 that it had 'provided' the $1.35 million USD, implying that all Chinese funds had been disbursed (see pg.4 of 'CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008').
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China National Petroleum Corporation provides $1.35 million USD to set up a scholarship for Kazakhstani students to study in China

# Description
On September 27, 2004, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) signed an agreement with the Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan in which CNPC agreed to provide $1.35 million USD to the ministry for the creation of the "Presidential Scholarship." The scholarship was to finance higher level education in China for excellent Kazakhstani students. The scholarship fund was active as of September 2011.
justification: Project is focused on education and human development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Scholarship program for Kazakhstani students to study in China, funded by CNPC but focused on education
